page.title: 19ALL ENGLAND JUMPING COURSE
page.content: Further information from the "Evening Argus" (Brighton), w/c 14th October 1985. Millionaire Hickstead owner Douglas Bunn is making a bid for a cut in the Â£18,000 rates bill for his famous jumping course. He believes he has a strong case for reduction because of fewer meetings are now held. Hickstead has fought to keep its prices down for the public. 20 years ago a ticket cost Â£1, it is now Â£2. Mr. Bunn said, "Tickets would be Â£6 each now if they were linked to inflation." Mr. Bunn added that the rate application had nothing to do with the proposed change to the A23 next to the ground. Two years ago, meetings at the course, which attracted the world's best riders, were cut from four to three to save on costs
